pyndigo.common module

This module contain the basic classes upon which INDIGO clients, drivers and agents are built. Particularly they encapsulate the logic for Properties and Items.

Classes

PyndigoItem

An item which can be contained into a PyndigoProperty. This is where the values for the properties are really stored.

PyndigoProperty

An INDIGO Property to store one or more items. They have a particular type (Text, Number, Switch, Light, Blob)

Constants

STATE_OK

Ok State for a PyndigoProperty.

STATE_BUSY

Busy State for a PyndigoProperty.

STATE_ALERT

Alert State for a PyndigoProperty.

STATE_IDLE

Idle State for a PyndigoProperty.

LIGHT_OK

Ok value for a light PyndigoItem.

LIGHT_BUSY

Busy value for a light PyndigoItem.

LIGHT_ALERT

Alert value for a light PyndigoItem.

LIGHT_IDLE

Idle value for a light PyndigoItem.

TYPE_TEXT

Type Text for a PyndigoProperty or a PyndigoItem.

TYPE_NUMBER

Type Number for a PyndigoProperty or a PyndigoItem.

TYPE_SWITCH

Type Switch for a PyndigoProperty or a PyndigoItem.

TYPE_LIGHT

Type Light for a PyndigoProperty or a PyndigoItem.

TYPE_BLOB

Type BLOB for a PyndigoProperty or a PyndigoItem.

RULE_ONE_OF_MANY

Rule OneOfMany for a switch PyndigoProperty.

RULE_AT_MOST_ONE

Rule AtMostOne for a switch PyndigoProperty.

RULE_ANY_OF_MANY

Rule AnyOfMany for a switch PyndigoProperty.

SWITCH_ON

Switch value On for a PyndigoItem.

SWITCH_OFF

Switch value Off for a PyndigoItem.

PERM_RW

Permissions rw (read / write) for a PyndigoProperty.

PERM_RO = “ro”

Permissions ro (read only) for a PyndigoProperty.

PERM_WO = “wo”

Permissions wo (write only) for a PyndigoProperty.

class pyndigo.common.PyndigoItem(parent_property: PyndigoProperty, name: str = None, value=None, label: str = '', number_format: str = None, min_value=None, max_value=None, step=None, hints: str = None, _decoded_json=None)[source]

Bases: object

An item which can be contained into a PyndigoProperty. This is where the values for the properties are really stored.

Usually these objects are not created with the class constructor:

  • If you develop a Client, the Properties and Items will be automatically created when the Property is received from the Server.

  • If you develop a Driver, you should create the Items using the methods:

    • PyndigoProperty.add_text(...)

    • PyndigoProperty.add_number(...)

    • PyndigoProperty.add_switch(...)

    • PyndigoProperty.add_light(...)

    • PyndigoProperty.add_blob(...)

__init__(parent_property: PyndigoProperty, name: str = None, value=None, label: str = '', number_format: str = None, min_value=None, max_value=None, step=None, hints: str = None, _decoded_json=None)[source]

Constructs a new PyndigoItem. If you are developing an INDIGO Client, an INDIGO Driver or an agent you MUST NOT use this constructor.

get_property() → PyndigoProperty[source]

Gets the parent property to which the item belongs.

Returns:

The parent property to which the item belongs.

PyndigoProperty

str

Gets the label of the item (usually used in GUIs).

Returns:

The label of the item.

Return type:

str

get_value()[source]

Gets the value of the item.

Returns:

The value of the item. For text, switch, light and blob items it returns a str. For number items it may return a number or str (depending on the format).

Return type:

str or number

set_value(value)[source]

Sets the value of the item. If you are developing a Client, you MUST NOT use this method. You should use…

Parameters:

value (str or number) – The value to be set on the item. Use only when developing a Driver.

get_type() → str[source]

Gets the type of the item.

Returns:

One of TYPE_TEXT, TYPE_NUMBER, TYPE_SWITCH, TYPE_LIGHT or TYPE_BLOB

Return type:

str

class pyndigo.common.PyndigoProperty(device, prop_type: str, name: str = '', state: str = '', perm: str = '', label: str = '', group: str = '', timeout=0, timestamp: str = None, message: str = '', rule: str = None, hints=None, _decoded_json=None)[source]

Bases: object

A property of a particular type (TYPE_TEXT, TYPE_NUMBER, TYPE_SWITCH, TYPE_LIGHT or TYPE_BLOB).

Usually these objects are not created with the class constructor:

  • If you develop a Client, the Properties and Items will be automatically created when the Property is received from the Server.

  • If you develop a Driver, you should create the Properties using the methods:

    • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_text_property(...)

    • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_number_property(...)

    • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_switch_property(...)

    • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_light_property(...)

    • PyndigoDriverDevice.add_blob_property(...)

__init__(device, prop_type: str, name: str = '', state: str = '', perm: str = '', label: str = '', group: str = '', timeout=0, timestamp: str = None, message: str = '', rule: str = None, hints=None, _decoded_json=None)[source]

Constructs a new PyndigoProperty. If you are developing an INDIGO Client, an INDIGO Driver or an agent you MUST NOT use this constructor.

add_text(name: str, value: str, label: str = None, hints: str = None) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Adds a new Text Item to the Property

Parameters:

  • parent_property (PyndigoProperty) – The property to which this item belongs.

  • name (str) – The name of the property. Usually UPPERCASE_UNDERSCORED

  • value (str) – The initial value for the property

  • label (str, optional) – A readable name for the property, usually used in GUIs, by default None

  • hints (str, optional) – Some hints to format the GUI for the new text item. Check INDIGO docs for more details, by default None

Returns:

The Property itself (in case of need chaining calls)

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

add_number(name: str, value: str, number_format: str, min_value, max_value, step, label: str = None, hints: str = None) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Adds a new Number Item to the Property

Parameters:

  • parent_property (PyndigoProperty) – The property to which this item belongs.

  • name (str) – The name of the property. Usually UPPERCASE_UNDERSCORED

  • value (str) – The initial value for the property

  • number_format (str) – The number format description of the item. Check INDI White paper for more details

  • min_value (number or str) – Minimum value for the property

  • max_value (number or str) – Maximum value for the property

  • step (number or str) – Steps (increments) for the value, by default 1

  • label (str, optional) – A readable name for the property, usually used in GUIs, by default None

  • hints (str, optional) – Some hints to format the GUI for the new text item. Check INDIGO docs for more details, by default None

Returns:

The Property itself (in case of need chaining calls)

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

add_switch(name: str, value: str, label: str = None, hints: str = None) → PyndigoProperty[source]

Adds a new Switch Item to the Property

Parameters:

  • parent_property (PyndigoProperty) – The property to which this item belongs.

  • name (str) – The name of the property. Usually UPPERCASE_UNDERSCORED

  • value (str) – The initial value for the property

  • label (str, optional) – A readable name for the property, usually used in GUIs, by default None

  • hints (str, optional) – Some hints to format the GUI for the new text item. Check INDIGO docs for more details, by default None

Returns:

The Property itself (in case of need chaining calls)

Return type:

PyndigoProperty

Gets the PyndigoItem with a given name.

Parameters:

item_name (str) – The name of the item

Returns:

The item with the given name. None if there is no item with this name in the property.

Return type:

PyndigoItem

get_items() → dict[str, pyndigo.common.PyndigoItem][source]

Get the Items of this Property.

Returns:

A dictionary with the Items of the Property. keys = name of the property and value = the property.

Return type:

dict[str, PyndigoItem]

get_type() → str[source]

Gets the type of the property.

Returns:

One of TYPE_TEXT, TYPE_NUMBER, TYPE_SWITCH, TYPE_LIGHT or TYPE_BLOB.

Return type:

str

is_text() → bool[source]

Checks if the property is of TYPE_TEXT.

Returns:

True if the property type is TYPE_TEXT.

False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

set_ok() → None[source]

Sets the state of the property as STATE_OK.

Do not use for Clients development, just for Drivers.

set_busy() → None[source]

Sets the state of the property as STATE_BUSY.

Do not use for Clients development, just for Drivers.

set_alert() → None[source]

Sets the state of the property as STATE_ALERT.

Do not use for Clients development, just for Drivers.

set_idle() → None[source]

Sets the state of the property as STATE_IDLE.

Do not use for Clients development, just for Drivers.

Return type:

str

get_state() → str[source]

Gets the state of the property.

Returns:

The state of the property. That is, one of STATE_OK, STATE_BUSY, STATE_ALERT or STATE_IDLE.

Return type:

str

get_perm() → str[source]

Gets the permissions of the property.

Returns:

The permissions of the property, that is, one of pyndigo.common.PERM_RW, pyndigo.common.PERM_RO or pyndigo.common.PERM_WO.

Return type:

str
